From UX designer to digital design superhuman

My 3-step plan to fix UX by reclaiming craft, depth, and real design thinking.

If I have to see one more persona named “Emily, 32, loves yoga and oat lattes”, I might just give up and start an AI-powered newsletter, post design inspirational BS on LinkedIn, and call myself a ‘Design Evangelist.’ There was a time when design meant solving problems creatively, not just filling out templates with stock empathy.

I remember writing about how simple UX was if all the fundamentals were covered. Six years have passed and UX has become a temple of rituals: the double diamond is its holy scripture, personas its prayer beads, and workshops its weekly mass. But for all this ceremony, where is the soul of design?

“The UX job market is a mess”, as Jared M. Spool clearly explained in his post, and I agree with him. Even Shopify got rid of fancy job titles and just calls everyone a ‘Designer’ now. That’s a sign that something’s not right.

Let’s talk about the mess, and how I would fix it.

A bit of history

Roughly 20 years ago, the design world had clear professional distinctions. Designers were classified by the outcome of their work: industrial design, graphic design, interior design…
